summary: Mobile-first spiritual reflection app/platform called "Gita Saar" for ages 13–25, featuring a Gen‑Z Hinglish "best-friend Krishna" chatbot, full Bhagavad Gita verse browsing with a fixed 4-column verse card format + action step, mood-based discovery, and an app-like UI with bottom navigation, dark mode, and updated styling preference: pink background with suitably-used purple typography.
architectural_notes: Mobile-first app-like IA with bottom navigation: Home / Read Gita / Talk to Krishna / Discover.
Chatbot outputs must follow a strict verse card structure (Sanskrit + Hindi meaning + English meaning + Gen‑Z interpretation) and always end with a small action step.
AI behavior constraints: Hinglish Gen‑Z best-friend Krishna; multi-turn clarifying questions; no judgment/preaching; in-session context memory; not therapy/medical advice.
Design system: soft pastel minimal UI, rounded components, micro-animations, and dark mode.
Product constraint: 100% free (no paywalls, no guilt nudging).
UI color constraint: primary background should be pink; use purple for typography/word accents in a readable, consistent way across light/dark modes.
Verse card translation fields should be explicitly "Literal Hindi translation" and "Literal English translation" (not paraphrases), alongside Sanskrit and Gen‑Z interpretation.
User requested a top menu/navigation bar (Home/Read Gita/Discover/Ask Krishna) in addition to existing app navigation expectations.
Discover emotions should be hardcoded as selectable boxes/cards with verse suggestions and coping guidance per emotion.
Read Gita chapter pages requested as tabular verse rows (verse + Hindi meaning + English meaning + Gen‑Z interpretation).
known_issues: Build/deployment attempts failed due to an internal configuration issue and an inability to implement the request via the build tool.
imageRequirements:
## Edit Images
- Increase visibility and prominence of the floral decoration while keeping a soft pastel style (flowers-corner.dim_1024x1024.png > flowers-corner-prominent.dim_1024x1024.png)

existing_features.title: Create the core mobile-first app shell with bottom navigation containing exactly four main sections: Home, Read Gita, Talk to Krishna, and Discover. The experience must feel app-like and thumb-friendly, with routing/state that preserves the current tab and scroll position per tab during the session.

Implement the mandatory UI/UX style direction across the app: soft pastel palette (peach, blush, ivory, saffron accents), minimal airy spacing, rounded cards and pill buttons, and smooth subtle micro-animations (e.g., gentle hover/press, soft ‘breathing’ on key cards). Add a user-accessible dark mode and ensure all pages are readable and visually consistent in both light and dark themes.

Build the Home page ‘emotional hook’ hero section with the exact headline and subtext provided, plus three primary CTAs: “Open today’s wisdom”, “Find by mood”, and “Talk to Krishna”. The CTAs must navigate to the corresponding sections and be prominently reachable by thumb on mobile.

Implement the Read Gita section with: (1) an 18-chapter listing screen using clean chapter cards that show English chapter name, Sanskrit subtitle, and verse count; (2) a chapter detail screen listing all verses for that chapter; and (3) a verse detail/card view. The content must be ‘zero intimidation’ with clear hierarchy and approachable copy.

Standardize the verse display format everywhere (Read Gita, Discover, Today’s wisdom, and Chat responses) to the required 4-column ‘Verse Card Layout’: Column 1 Sanskrit (original shloka, clean typography, optional toggle), Column 2 Hindi meaning (simple conversational Hindi), Column 3 English meaning (plain modern English), Column 4 Gen-Z Krishna interpretation (first-person Krishna voice in Hinglish, relatable). Every verse card must end with exactly one small, doable ‘Action step’.

Build the Discover section as ‘Find by feeling’ with exactly six mood cards (Anxious, Lost, Angry, Sad, Motivated, Calm) using the provided short mood taglines. Each mood page must show curated verses, short Gen-Z explanations, and a CTA “Talk to Krishna about this” that opens Talk to Krishna with the mood preselected/attached for the current session.

Implement the Talk to Krishna chatbot UI with mandatory input methods: text input and a voice input button (speech-to-text in the browser). Provide friendly placeholder prompts exactly in Hinglish, including: “Bol, kya chal raha hai dimaag mein?” and “Jo feel ho raha hai, bol de…”. The chat UI must support multi-turn conversation and show responses that include the standard Verse Card format plus an action step.

Enforce strict Krishna personality and conversation behavior rules in chatbot responses: Hinglish output, wise best-friend tone (calm, slightly playful, emotionally intelligent), no shaming/judgment/preaching, asks clarifying follow-up questions, and remembers context within the same session. Responses must avoid dumping too much content at once (progressive depth).

Add AI safety and content boundaries across the app (especially chat): clearly communicate it is not therapy or medical advice, focus on emotional grounding, encourage reflection without dependency, and avoid instructions that could be interpreted as medical guidance. Include an in-chat safety footer or an accessible info modal linked from the chat screen.
Ensure monetization stays 100% free: do not add paywalls, subscriptions, upsells, or guilt nudges anywhere in the UI.

Provide build deliverables inside the codebase as developer-facing documentation: full app/site structure, UX flow notes, chatbot response logic description, UI layout notes, and at least 3 sample multi-turn conversations that demonstrate the tone, follow-up questioning, verse card output, and action step ending.

Update the global visual theme to use a pink background across the platform and apply purple typography accents appropriately (headlines, key labels, links, active navigation, and emphasis text) while maintaining readability and consistency in both light and dark mode.

Refine the overall UI/UX to match the attached screenshot styling direction (soft pink canvas, airy spacing, rounded cards, serif-forward hero headings where appropriate, and clean navigation states) and fix visual inconsistencies across pages (spacing, card elevation, typography hierarchy, and button styles).

Update the verse presentation UI so each verse is displayed in the required 4-part format with clear labels: Sanskrit (original), Literal Hindi translation, Literal English translation, and Gen‑Z interpretation; keep the action step clearly separated and always visible within the verse card.

Enhance the Read Gita chapter listing screen to include an in-page search/filter input for chapters (by English title and Sanskrit subtitle) to match the usability shown in the screenshots, without changing the existing app’s four-tab structure.

Add a sticky Home page top menu bar with four buttons labeled exactly: "Home", "Read Gita", "Discover", and "Ask Krishna". Clicking "Home" must scroll to the top of the Home page content (not change tabs). Clicking the other three buttons must navigate to the existing corresponding app tabs (Read Gita, Discover, and the AI chatbot tab).

Add devotional visual elements to the UI by incorporating (a) floral decoration(s) and (b) a Lord Krishna picture in a way that matches the current attached styling direction (soft pink canvas, airy spacing, rounded cards) and stays readable in both light and dark mode.

Update the Read Gita chapter detail presentation so each chapter displays a table where each row corresponds to a verse and the columns show: (1) Verse identifier (chapter:verse and/or verse number) and verse text (Sanskrit optional), (2) Hindi meaning, (3) English meaning, and (4) Gen-Z style interpretation.

Update the Home page hero layout so that “Open today’s wisdom” and “Find by mood” render side-by-side (parallel) directly under the hero subtext (“The Bhagavad Gita — decoded for overthinkers, anxious minds, and curious Gen-Z souls.”) and are visible without scrolling on typical mobile viewports.
Update the Home page hero layout so that the “Talk to Krishna” CTA is moved next to the Lord Krishna picture (portrait) rather than being stacked below the “Find by mood” button.
Make the floral visuals in the Home page background more prominent while preserving readability of foreground hero text and CTAs in both light and dark mode.
Make the top menu bar (buttons labeled exactly: “Home”, “Read Gita”, “Discover”, “Ask Krishna”) visible on all pages/tabs (Home, Read Gita, Discover, Talk to Krishna), not only on the Home page.

Change navigation scroll behavior so that when a user opens any tab/page, it starts at the top of that page (do not preserve previous per-tab scroll position). Also ensure internal view changes within Read Gita (chapter list → chapter detail → verse detail → back) start at the top of the newly shown view.
Ensure the Read Gita chapter list displays all 18 chapters and show each chapter’s total verse count in brackets in the list UI (e.g., “(47)”).

new_feature_requests.summary: Define full site/app structure + UX flow (mobile-first, app-like, bottom navigation: Home / Read Gita / Talk to Krishna / Discover)
Home page emotional hook with hero headline/subtext and primary CTAs (today’s wisdom, find by mood, talk to Krishna)
"Talk to Krishna" chatbot with strict Gen‑Z Hinglish personality rules + multi-turn clarifying conversation behavior + in-session context memory
Chat input methods: text input + voice input (speech-to-text) with friendly Hinglish placeholders
Standardize verse response output: 4-column verse card (Sanskrit, Hindi meaning, English meaning, Gen‑Z Krishna interpretation) + mandatory small action step
Read Gita section: all 18 chapters listing with chapter cards (English name + Sanskrit subtitle + verse count) and verse list views
For every verse in verse list: include Sanskrit + Hindi meaning + English meaning + Gen‑Z interpretation + action step (consistent with verse card format)
Discover page: mood-based cards (anxious/lost/angry/sad/motivated/calm) that show curated verses, short Gen‑Z explanations, and CTA to talk to Krishna
UI/UX design direction: soft pastel palette, minimal airy spacing, rounded cards/pill buttons, smooth micro-animations, thumb-friendly layout, and dark mode
AI safety rules: not therapy replacement, no medical advice, emotional grounding focus, encourage reflection not dependency
Monetization constraint: 100% free, no paywalls, no guilt nudging
Provide sample conversations, AI response logic, UI layout suggestions, and component-level build guidance as deliverables

Implement backend data and APIs to support: all 18 chapters, all verses (with Sanskrit, Hindi meaning, English meaning, Gen-Z Krishna interpretation, and action step), mood-to-verse curation mappings, and a deterministic ‘today’s wisdom’ selection. Provide query methods that the frontend can call to fetch chapters, verses by chapter, a single verse, curated verses by mood, and today’s verse reference/content.

Implement chatbot response logic on the backend that selects an appropriate verse based on (a) user-selected mood (if present), (b) simple keyword/emotion matching from the user’s message, and (c) recent conversation context passed from the client for the current session. The backend must return a structured response object containing: selected verse content (all fields needed for the VerseCard), a short supportive message in Hinglish, 1–2 clarifying follow-up questions, and an action step (or use the verse’s action step).
UI theme update: keep overall background color pink and use purple in words/typography suitably across the platform while maintaining readability and the existing app-like layout.

Content spec update: ensure verse display uses literal Hindi translation and literal English translation fields (in addition to Sanskrit and Gen‑Z interpretation) consistently across all chapters/verses in the 4-column format.

Populate the backend with the complete Gita Saar content: all 18 chapters and every verse for each chapter, ensuring each verse includes (1) Sanskrit original verse, (2) literal Hindi translation, (3) literal English translation, and (4) Gen‑Z interpretation, plus exactly one action step per verse.
Add a top menu/navigation bar with buttons: Home (scrolls to top), Read Gita, Discover, and Ask Krishna (chatbot) for mobile-compatible navigation.
Update Discover UI to show hardcoded emotion boxes and, for each emotion, suggest relevant Gita verses plus guidance/suggestions for handling that emotion.
Add devotional UI imagery elements (flowers and a Lord Krishna picture) while keeping the attached UI styling direction.
Change Read Gita chapter detail presentation to a table per chapter where each row shows: verse, Hindi meaning, English meaning, and Gen‑Z style interpretation.
Global navigation/scroll behavior updates: top menu bar should be visible on all pages (not just Home) and every page/tab should open scrolled to the top when navigated to.

Home page layout refinements: move “Talk to Krishna” CTA next to Krishna’s picture; place “Open today’s wisdom” and “Find by mood” CTAs side-by-side directly under the main headline; adjust typography/spacing so these CTAs are visible on initial view; make background floral elements more prominent.
